author: dmarz12
content: Ah okay that makes sense thank you! And out of curiosity, why does SSZ require a fixed upper limit?

author: ajsutton
content: Just the way SSZ works. All lists have a maximum bound on size. It does provide some nice security benefits, for example we can reject gossip that exceeds the maximum possible size for the object type we're expecting. These very huge fields negate that benefit but there's a lot of things it does help with.

author: benjaminion
content: It allows us to use generalised indices when constructing Merkle proofs. I've written about SSZ and included some info here, https://eth2book.info/latest/part2/building_blocks/ssz, but the generalised indices section is just a stub for now as we're not really using it yet. Basically, if objects occupy a fixed number of (possibly "virtual") leaves in the Merkle tree then you can assign a unique index to any element of the tree. It will be super useful for light clients.

author: ajsutton
content: ah yes, I forgot about generalised indices.  They are indeed very useful and we take advantage of them in a number of places in Teku.
